Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports data collection on Syrian refugees' experience being accepted by IcelandThe conflict in Syria has added to a global refugee crisis that is one of the largest in history with an estimated 20 million known refugees currently displaced. While Syrian refugees were forced from their country due to war, it is estimated that by the year 2050 potentially 200 million people could be displaced due to environmental change from a warming climate. These changes are not only affecting life-ways around the world but are also influencing the role of nations in these crises. In early 2016, Iceland received Syrian refugee families and placed them in three Icelandic communities. Now is an exceptional time to examine Iceland's reaction and capacity to address forced migration into the Arctic. There is great potential in Iceland to serve as a global model as it determines policies, procedures, and communications among the stakeholders for developing best-practices for addressing the challenges of refugees and forced migration. Providing culturally effective services to a population that continuously changes in country of origin, language needs, health and mental health needs, and cultural experiences will be a significant problem for service providers around the world. Knowledge gained through this research has the potential to provide critical insights other nations facing similar crises.

This project will examine service provision to refugees and their families (language services, social services, health services, education, job training) in Iceland. The broader impact of this research project is in its potential to contribute to the development of effective and culturally appropriate services for refugees. The PI will conduct qualitative interviews with refugees and providers twice in a 12-month period starting in the summer of 2016 through the winter of 2017. This project will build on early data collected in the winter of 2016, as Iceland prepared for the arrival of Syrian families. The research was supported by Iceland's Ministry of Welfare that requested the PI of this project, a Fulbright Specialist in refugee resettlement, meet with providers and administrators from welfare, education, health, and other agencies that would be involved in the resettlement of the Syrian refugee families. The PI facilitated discussions on the needs of the service providers and communities who would be receiving refugee families. This project will continue those discussions six months after the Syrian families arrival and then 12 months after the arrival. This research has the potential to inform healthcare providers, social service workers and administrators, policy makers, educators, and community agencies on the development of best practices in resettling refugees and forced migrants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Syrian Refugee Families in Iceland

What is the issue and why it is important

            The current global refugee crisis is the largest in history with nearly 66 million people displaced due to conflict, economic hardships, and climate-change environmental challenges. There is great need to learn the best practices for working with refugees and forced migrants. Our current global crisis demonstrates this. There is also great need for countries to understand how to resettle refugees and forced migrants during their first year of arrival and as they integrate and adapt into their new communities.

In early 2016 Iceland received Syrian refugee families in three communities. Iceland is in a unique position to develop a refugee response system that avoids some of the challenges other countries have faced. It is relatively new to receiving refugees. For example, the United States historically received nearly 80,000 refugees each year. And while the United States is experienced in providing health and mental health services to refugees, it has also had to react to each new arriving group’s needs and situation.  This has caused agencies to work in silos from each other, often unwittingly duplicating services or ignoring needs. In addition, as an island nation, Iceland can control the influx of refugees. There is great potential in Iceland to determine policies, procedures, and communications among the stakeholders to execute best-practice for working with refugees and forced migrants.

 

What this study did

            This study examined the experiences of providers of refugee services in Iceland and the recipients of those services. In the summer of 2016 and again in the winter of 2017, program managers and social workers were interviewed from three municipalities regarding their experiences in developing and providing resettlement services for Syrian refugee families that arrived in the first quarter of 2016. In addition, adult members of the Syrian families were interviewed about their experiences receiving the services. The interviews captured the participants’ experiences at six-months and one-year after the families arrived in Iceland.

What was learned

  1. The value of communication among the agencies: The program managers and providers developed systems of communicating among the involved agencies. In preparing for the families’ arrivals, there were weekly meetings among the providers, program managers, and other involved institutions, such as school administrators, red cross managers, and child welfare workers. These meetings reviewed day-to-day concerns. In addition, there were monthly meetings with administrators from the Ministry and providing agencies that reviewed the overall needs and progress of the programs. These meetings continued throughout the resettlement period and was essential to a well-managed program that decreased a silo effect.
  2. That communities need to be prepared: The providers became acutely aware that preparation for resettlement was about preparing the community as much as preparing for the families. They worked with the media to provide positive narratives of the program, provided forums for communities to address concerns and questions, and were responsive to communities’ fears that the families received resources that the residents should have. This has important implications for cities throughout the world that seek to increase the likelihood of positive relations between the host community and the new arrivals. How might other cities prepare their communities?
  3. Resettlement is a long-term project: The providers felt that the true outcome of the program would not be just at the one-year mark, but also in years to come. How comfortable and functioning were the family members in two years, three, or five years from the end of the program? Had the resettlement program provided the foundation needed for successful integration? While this study didn’t evaluate the effectiveness of the program in these terms, considering outcomes as long-term goals may be helpful for other cities and agencies as they work toward best-practices.
  4. That programs need flexibility: The families have needs that were at times difficult to predict. The providers stated they were better prepared to receive more families but had a deeper understanding that there are many issues and individual characteristics that define the resettlement experience, making it difficult to expect one approach to work for all refugees. Like in many other settings, services were best when individualized for the uniqueness of each individual and family.
  5. That it is helpful to know the history of the refugee: The personal mental health history of the individual followed the new arrival, meaning, their strengths and challenges prior to resettlement would play a role in life after resettlement.
  6. That language and work were key elements: Of all the stressors faced by the families, the providers and families agreed that language acquisition and self-supporting work that matched their skills and training were key factors and prime areas of stress and worry.
